Name: Monopoly: Rhode Island
Description: Rhode Island Monopoly combines the classic game of Monopoly with a Rhode Island touch.  Well-known Rhode Island based businesses replace the properties and even the community chests.

Name: Duco
Description:
The Kingdom is at the brink of civil war. Diplomats and Chancellors from different parts of the land have come to the King's court to solve the conflicts between the different opposing factions. However, among the Diplomats there is a Traitor - with chaos in his mind. If he can turn the other Diplomats at each other, or eliminate enough Chancellors, total chaos will erupt in the Kingdom, and the Traitor will be greatly rewarded...

At the beginning of the game players are secretly assigned the roles of one Traitor the rest being Senators. Each player receives three advisers (that act like life points) and a counter is placed in the middle of a 20 or 30 (depending on # of players) diplomatic point track. The Senators win by taking the point count to 30 or eliminating the Traitor's all three advisers. The Traitor wind respectively by taking the point count to 0 or when all the advisers of a senator have been eliminated.

The heart of the game lies in negotiation and bluffing. The game is played using action cards that manipulate the diplomatic point track, number of advisers in the game and the ever useful resource of gold. Much like in Werewolf, the task of the Traitor is to turn the Senators against one other while getting away with actions with which he tries to end the game in his favour.

Name: Game of 45
Description:
This game is played on a board with 10 x 10 squares. The goal of the game is to create a line (horizontal, vertical or diagonal) on the board that contains one of each number (the sum of which equals 45, hence the name of the game).

Each player has a rack with ten numbers on it. Each turn, he may take one of two actions:
1) Draw a new tile, and:
a) Place a tile from his rack on the board, and add the newly drawn tile to his rack, or;
b) Place the newly drawn tile on the board;
2) Take a tile from the board and replace it with a tile from his rack.

Whenever a tile is placed on the board, it may not be placed in a row that already contains the same number. The round ends when a player manages to complete one row on the board (or two, in a two player game) while also having completed 'row' on his rack. All players now score points, and a new round starts. The game continues until a agreed-upon number of rounds has been played, or an agreed-upon score is reached.

Home page: http://www.gameof45.com/

Name: Mythos Miniatures
Description:
Mythos Miniatures is a self-published skirmish game set in Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos universe. The mechanics are based on Graeme Dawson's DWMG engine. It is a character driven system more akin to RPGs like Trail of Cthulhu and Call of Cthulhu than wargames.

Miniatures must be bought separately from other companies, such as eM-4 Miniatures, RAFM, Hasslefree and Shadowforge (or any of the licenced Call of Cthulhu Miniatures ranges).
Families: Series: action engine (Crooked Dice Game Design Studio)

Name: Into The Rubble
Description:
From the publisher:

Into The Rubble (ITR) offers players the opportunity to do cardboard battle in cities and railroad yards. The scenarios range from 1938 to 1945 with a variety of forces including American, Chinese, German/SS, Hungarian, Japanese, Nationalist Spanish, Republican Spanish, Romanian and Russian.

The Battlepack includes the following:

8 Action-Packed Scenarios. 
Two 8"x22" Geomorphic mapboards, printed on heavy card stock, depicting city and railroad yard terrain (BFP A, BFP B). 
One 8"x12" geomorphic Rubbled City overlay (RC-1), 1 large Factory overlay and 1 sheet of Debris overlays. 
Rules pages describing new terrain, including Railroad Factories. 
The Rubbled City overlay (RC-1) fits on other official ASL (MMP) city boards: 1, 20, 21, 22, 45, 49, and 51. 
Ownership of the following Multiman Publishing products are required to play all 8 of the included scenarios: Beyond Valor©, Yanks©, Doomed Battalions©, Armies of Oblivion©, Red Barricades©. Ownership of the following Heat of Battle products are required to play 1 of the included scenarios: Recon By Fire 4©.

Expands:

    Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1
    Yanks: ASL Module 3
    Doomed Battalions: ASL Module 11
    Armies of Oblivion: ASL Module 12
    Red Barricades: ASL Historical Module 1

Name: Great Fires
Description:
New York: December 16-17, 1835
Chicago: October 8-10, 1871 
Boston: November 9-10, 1872
Seattle: June 6, 1889
San Francisco: April 18-21, 1906

What do all these dates have in common? They mark some of the most catastrophic fires in U.S. history in which thousands and thousands of lives were lost, and enormous sections of these major metropolitans were reduced to little more than ash and amber.

Most city building games require construction from the ground up. But with 'Great Fires', players find out what happens when their beautiful city is, in its prime, under siege of fires raging out of control.

Great Fires is a fast paced game where the object is to be the least devastated of all players at the end of the game. Each player chooses one city (New York, Chicago, Boston, Seattle or San Francisco) and each game the fires begin in different districts. The mechanics for the spreading of fires can be fierce, luckily players are given some tools to help contain the fires--however the tools are limited, and will not be able to protect all of your city.

Prevent as many fatalities as possible, keep your city from burning completely to the ground, and you just might be able to come out on top!

Name: Hund herum!
Description:
Turbulent roulette for delicious bones...

On your marks! Get set! Woof! Time after time the ball rolls through the gardens with the naughty dogs in pursuit. Where the ball stops, the dogs uncover some tasty bones. Whoever collects the most bones, whether by skill or by luck, will be crowned the leader of the pack. Exciting to the end, because dog-roulette always has a surprising twist.

Name: Der Goldene Kompass: Das Kartenspiel zum Film
Description:
Players take turns playing cards from their hand to a central pool. The player earns points by playing a card, whose value matches the value of either one or more cards already in the pool, or the sum of several cards already in the pool. In either case, the player wins all the cards in the set and places them in their score pile.

The round ends when the draw pile has been emptied: Points are awarded for the yellow 7, for the most yellow cards, and for the most total cards. In addition, you can win a point for clearing the table.

The game ends after a set number of round.

Re-implements: 

    Scopa
    Gelb gewinnt!

Name: Chicago's Finest
Description:
Sometimes the bad guys pull off a big heist, and sometimes the good guys can stop the crime before it happens. But in the long run, it’s all about style.

In Chicago’s Finest, you take the role of the titular boys in blue, or their nemesis, the mob. Both sides are working hard to either perpetuate or prevent crime - but their primary concern is looking sharp.

Players tactically deploy cards representing guys, weapons, tools, and even K9 units in attempt to conjure up precisely enough cool to match the crime of the day. How much style is needed is determined by the Time, Day, Neighborhood, Location, and type of Crime – which change every day. The game lasts seven days.

Chicago’s Finest is quick, free to print out, and different every time you play it. Game mechanics somewhat resemble Blackjack, but with a variable target number, as well as an arsenal of tricks and card synergies that let you manipulate your and your opponent’s card total.

Download the game in the BGG Files section.

Name: ChronoCrisis
Description:
Thanks to a nasty computer virus, most of the researchers from University of Chicago’s Department of Temporal Archeology are lost somewhere in time.

In ChronoCrisis, players take on the role of crafty collegiate researchers to collect clues that can lead to the whereabouts and whenabouts of their lost colleagues. The trick, of course, is to minimize interaction with the “natives” and not damage the flow of history.

Players search for clues in five different time periods – Ancient Greece, Legendary Baghdad, Feudal Japan, Elizabethan England, and the Harlem Renaissance – in attempt to deduce and pinpoint the location of the lost time travelers.

Players collect clue cards through detective work, and can also steal clue cards from their unsuspecting opponents. When a player collects a set of clues from the same time period, he or she can attempt to make contact and confirm if the individual they’ve been tracking is indeed a fellow time traveler. The player’s hunches will often be correct. But invariably these hunches are sometimes wrong, and players have to plan ahead to make sure they’re able to deal with feisty natives.

The first player to rescue five lost time travelers wins. The catch, however, is that this target number of five increases whenever a player encounters a native.

ChronoCrisis is a quick, free, print-and-play card game for 2-4 players.

Download the game in the BGG Files section.

Name: Der Zaubermeister
Description:
Players try to complete a new magic potion by gathering the correct coloured ingredients, which are then stored on shelves on the gameboard. The ingredient collection is based on the luck a die roll, but those that are not needed can also be traded.

Before the magic potion is brewed the colour oracle moves and players have to predict the resulting colour. If correct, the player gets to move forwards and thus move closer to star chamber, where they can claim the coveted magic hat. If the prediction is wrong, everyone gives the concoction an imaginative name... how about "Firefly-juice"?

The game comes with a set of water-soluble Faber-Castell colouring pencils and intends to promote creativity and the communication skills of children.

Name: Cartographer: The Card Game
Description:
In the mid-16th Century, Lord Date Masamune is consolidating his power in northeastern Japan. Masamune has decreed that the first person to document the vastness of this new kingdom will be honored with the title of “Shogun’s Cartographer.”

In Cartographer: The Card Game, players are ambitious mapmakers competing to complete a map of Masamune’s kingdom and win a place in the Shogun’s court.

Players hire Explorers and send them in one of the four cardinal directions to survey the lands and take notes toward what will eventually be a map of Masamune’s kingdom. Players may also hire Samurai, and Shinto Priests, who accompany the Explorers and help to fend off Oni, Kappa, Tengu, and other dangerous inhabitants of mythological Japan.

Explorers may also find treasure, be forced into a battle of wits with a sly Kitsune, or suffer the consequences of an earthquake.

Cartographer: The Card Game is a free print-and-play card game for 2-4 players.

Download the game in the BGG Files section.

Cartographer: The Card Game is a precursor to Cartographer: Vision of the Shogun.

Name: Stockholmsspelet
Description:
Each player leads a character that goes around the city and responds to questions about Stockholm. Each correct answer gives 10 "Stockholmscred." The goal is to visit all the districts. When a player has been able to cope with questions for all puzzles, the endgame can begin. At the end, all the players Stockholmscred are counted up and the player with most wins.

Complete description in Swedish can be found at http://www.stockholmsspelet.se/

Name: ROC 'n Lol
Description:
ROC 'n Lol is Dutch game designed for a school (ROC). It is actually a two-in-one-game, since the game can be played in two different ways.

1. Party and play
Can be played by two to five teams of two players each. Each team moves it's pawn by rolling a die and performing different actions (answering questions, guessing words, drawing pictures). Winner is the first team to reach the finish line.

2. Topper Coach
Can be played by 2 to 5 players. Each player has six students that need to graduate. These six students are guided through their education by playing out cards. Winner is the first player graduating all six students.

About the game name:
"ROC" is the name of the school type.
"Lol" is the Dutch word for "fun".

Name: Bedlam: The Countdown
Description:
From Mike Petty:

Bedlam:  The Countdown
This is a resource management and negotiation game set in the dark future.  Most simply, it's an auction game where the characters you buy provide the options you'll have for actions on your turn.  Instead of using the usual approach with character based card games--when cards refer to broad classes of characters such as "thief" or "wizard"--the cards in Bedlam refer to specific characters and they give the game an excellent sense of narrative.  Prepare for some surprises, some backstabbing and plenty of tough decisions.

I know that, as the game's creator, my own opinion doesn't count for much.  I have to say this is my favorite game of all that I have created.  I'm glad to be able offer it for the first time in this form.  I trust expansions and other editions will follow as more people discover the simple system and explore the possibilities it offers.

The game is for three to five players and it can be completed in 45- 60 minutes.  You'll need to print and cut out about 50 cards, a player sheet for each player and some counters (if you don't want to use poker chips or other tokens).

Name: Juristspelet
Description:
The players takes the roles of lawyers that have just started successful careers at well-reputed law firms. As litigation lawyers you will spend all your time processing in the country's public courts. Your want of challenges has lead you to enter into a prestigious bet with your friends. The one that manages to first win a case in the Supreme Court will have the respect of his peers for the rest of her/his career.

To achieve the goal of winning a process in the Supreme Court the players must work their way through the Swedish public court system. After winning processes in six different areas of the law in the municipal courts the players can move up and start processing in the courts of appeal. A process is won by correctly answering a juridical question.

Name: Alien Skirmish
Description: A game based on the Alien/Predator universe, in which the players control humans, aliens, or predators. It is played on a chess board or any similar 8x8 grid. Miniature figures or chits are used to represent the individual combatants. The object of the game is to destroy your opponent’s leader unit. Card play is central to the game. Cards drawn from a common deck are played to cause units to move and attack.

Name: Universal Fighting System: Darkstalkers
Description:
When it comes to card games, you know you're the best. Now prove it with fist-pounding bone-breaking attacks and perfectly timed blocks of the Darkstalkers™ Collectible Card Game.

As part of the Universal Fighting System (UFS), the action flows quickly between players as punches and kicks are thrown and grapples and throws are executed with deadly precision. You are one of the characters from Darkstalkers™ and you will become the champion!

Each booster contains 10 Darkstalkers CCG cards which are 100% compatible with the entire library of UFS collectible card games. Players need at least 1 UFS starter deck to used the cards within.

Name: Universal Fighting System
Description:
When it comes to card games, you know you're the best. Now prove it with fist-pounding bone-breaking attacks and perfectly timed blocks of the KING OF FIGHTERS 2006 and the SAMURAI SHOWDOWN Collectible Card Games.

As part of the Universal Fighting System (UFS), the action flows quickly between players as punches and kicks are thrown and grapples and throws are executed with deadly precision. You are one of the characters from KING OF FIGHTERS 2006 or from SAMURAI SHOWDOWN and you will become the champion!

The 60 card starter deck contains everything one player needs to start fighting in the UFS arena, including a rule sheet. It contains 3 exclusive cards, not available anywhere else.

Each booster contains 10 The King of Fighters 2006 and/or Samurai Showdown V CCG cards which are 100% compatible with the entire library of UFS collectible card games. Players need at least 1 UFS starter deck to used the cards within.

Name: Universal Fighting System: ShadoWar
Description:
In a history that never was, the greatest empires of Earth's past stand at the apex of their glory. In Rome, gladiators do battle in the Circus Maximus. The Pharaohs of the Nile raise great pyramid monuments to their own mortality. China builds its Forbidden City, and in India a young prince sits under a pipal tree and finds Enlightenment. In the north, the furious Vikings launch their long ships for another season of plunder and pillage, and beyond the Great Wall the Mongol clans gaze at the great Empires with greedy eyes. But behind the opulence and grandeur of the empires, beneath the petty border conflicts and barbaric raids, rages a hidden, secret war… the ShadoWar.

Keepers of a forgotten truth, the Order of the Celestial Dawn devote themselves to bringing Enlightenment to all mankind. They are opposed by the Covenant of Twilight, a secret organization bent on using their power to rule all the empires of man. With guile, wisdom, treachery, and stealth they fight in the shadows for the destiny of humanity, turning the course of history towards their own ends.

Throughout this land of mystery and wonder walk men and women possessed of supernatural power and ability. With bodies and minds honed by constant practice, these warriors are the forefront of the ShadoWar.

ShadoWar is a Customizable Card Game.

Name: Chestnut Burrs
Description: Four cards of the same design, numbered from 1 to 4, constitute a book. The winner of the game is the player having the most books at the end of play.

Name: Vegas the Game
Description: This is a roll & move game in which certain spaces allow the player to make a roulette bet, throw craps, play a hand of black jack, or play the slots.  The slots are played via flipping cards.  The game comes with 100 plastic poker chips in 4 colors.  The winner is the first to $20,000 or 1/5 of the chips.

Name: Hatfield's Parlor Base Ball
Description: Early baseball game that includes the board, a 60-card deck and 3 markers.

Name: Crossword Letter Game
Description:
A spelling game from the 1930s, which might best be described as a 'free-form' Scrabble. There are 48, 64 or 96 cards in different versions of this game. (The unrelated earlier Crossword Card Game had 52 cards.)

Cards are dealt, and each player spells words, attaching them to any existing words in "crossword" fashion. The first player to get rid of all their cards wins the round, and the other players add the value of their remaining cards to their score. Games ends when someone reaches 100 points, and LOW SCORE wins.

The letter cards, how many of each (2nd column) in a 96-card set, and their point values (3rd column):


      Free 2 10      I  2  8      R  4  6
        A  6  8      J  2  4      S  6  6
        B  2  4      K  2  6      T  6  6
        C  4  6      L  6  6      U  4  6
        D  2  4      M  4  6      V  2  4
        E  8  8      N  4  6      W  4  6
        F  2  2      O  6  6      X  2  1
        G  4  2      P  2  6      Y  2  2
        H  4  6      Q  2  2      Z  2  1

Name: Art of War: Ambush Alley Mini Campaign
Description:
Return to the fictional city of Dawala and the neighboring town of Fadiz, a hot-bed of criminal as well as insurgent activity! Join 2nd Platoon in a mission to thwart the plans of a criminal cartel to plunder a nation’s cultural treasures and use the proceeds to fund insurgent operations!
Gangsters, insurgents, and a statue of a winged lion-man with five legs! What more could you ask for from a mission?
Art of War is an Ambush Alley mini-campaign pack. It contains three interlocking scenarios that can be played separately or as part of a narrative campaign in which the outcome of each scenario affects those that follow it.
Art of War returns to Dawala, a fictional city introduced in The Three Block War, and the stalwart men of Lt. Meuse’s 2nd Platoon.
Dawala might be a trouble spot anywhere in Iraq, Afghanistan or, with a little tweaking, nearly any other trouble-spot in the world. Likewise, the details of “2nd Platoon” have been left purposefully vague – it might be a platoon of US Rangers, British Marines, or soldiers of any of the many nations currently involved in hot, distant places.

Expands:

    Ambush Alley! A Game of Modern Urban Combat

Name: Kittenwar
Description: Based on the Kittenwar website, this card game sets pairs of kittens against each other to see which is the cutest.  Although the basic game is based on War, there are three different variants that take advantage of five different stats per kitten: Agility, Speed, Stealth, Avian Observation Tactics, and Paw to Paw Combat.  Each of the 100 cards depicts a full-color photograph of a featured kitten from the website.

Name: Apples to Apples Niños
Description:
Apples to Apples Niños consists of two decks of cards in Spanish: Red Apple cards (persons, places, things, or events) and Green Apple cards (adjectives). Each turn, the current judge selects a Green Apple card and players try to pick a Red Apple card from their hands that best match that the chosen card. The judge then chooses the Red Apple card is most like the word on the Green Apple card. The judge gives the Green Apple card to the player whose Red Apple card was chosen.

Once a player has won a four Green Apple cards, that player wins.

Name: Monopoly: Mob Rule Expansion Deck
Description:
Here at last we have something that has been sorely lacking from Monopoly since its initial release. One of the things that soon sees it consigned to the cupboard once again to gather dust is the fact that, regardless of what little tweaks you make here and there, each game is essentially the same deja-vous experience.

With this brand new pack of thirty cards, players are once again put back in charge and are given the chance of adding some new flavour to the game. Designed to either replace one of the existing two decks (Chance or Community Chest) or act as a supplementary third deck, these new cards bring some Mafia clout to the table.

Each pack includes a set of instructions describing all the different ways in which these can enhance the game.

'15 Different Cards:'
Speed 
Tommy Gun Confession 
Change Of Management 
Swimming With The Fish 
Fire Bomb  
Protection Money  
Bootlegged Booze  
Money Laundering  
Getaway Plan  
Cash Drop  
Gambling Den  
Eviction 
Eviction: Heavy Handed 
Heist 
Heist: Double Crossed

'Example: Heist'
Card Wording: 
You're feeling lucky and decide to carry out a bank heist.

Roll a dice. 
1 & 2 
Close escape - miss a turn. 
3 & 4 
Planned to perfection - collect £500 from the bank. 
5 & 6 
Caught red handed - go to jail.

Expands:

    Monopoly

Name: Fronteira
Description: Game lived in the Middle Ages with collection of pieces in which the player assembles his kingdom, which builds castles, farms, villages and abbeys, Wars facing other kingdoms in wars of expansion, suffers attacks by Vikings, witchcraft and black fever, has factor luck by collecting points as well as parts of the game, strategic factor is reasonable.

Name: Nation's Treasures
Description:
Nation's Treasures is a card game inspired by Lost Cities. 
While retaining the classic Lost Cities 2-player rule, the game is designed with new 3-4 player rule. In new 3-4 player rule:
Cards are separated into 5 decks according to colors.
In the setup, players draw 2 cards randomly and flips the top card of each deck, then chooses to draw 2 cards.
Each time the top card is drawn, you flip up the top card.

Name: Reise nach Moskau
Description:
Reise nach Moskau is the game of Misha the Bear's travels across the USSR.

Players are dealt a hand of 8 city cards, representing cities in the USSR and 4 action cards which let them take special moves.

The object of the game is to play all your cards by moving from city to city and then return to Moscow when you have no cards in hand.  The player that does this first is the winner.

City cards are played just by moving to the corresponding city on the map (players familiar with Wildlife Adventure will see a similarity but this game does not use routes).

Action cards are played instead of moving and allow the player to do things such as fly to any city, force another player to draw an additional city card, or "invite" other players to join you in your city (quite annoying when you are heading to your final destination).

Name: Two Tigers Chess
Description:
A 2-2 players game based on the Old Chinese Game "Tiger Chess".
A more complex game, with 2 "tigers", and 12 "human".
"human" aim at to capture the tigers, by surrounding the tigers.
"tigers" aim at to eat "human", so that the human cannot capture the tigers.

Name: The Triangle Challenge
Description:
The Triangle Challenge - A Game of Strategy & Daring

The object for each player is to score the most points by creating triangles where all three end-points match the color of their wooden stacker.  The larger the triangle, the larger the point value.  The player with the most points after all 20 discs have been played, wins!

The Strategy - Strategy is the key to secretly loading your wooden stacker and selecting which move to make on every turn.  Each player controls 5 red and 5 blue discs.

The Dare - Daring is essential to out-fox your opponent on every turn.  Try to bluff and trick your opponent into helping you create more triangles of your color to win, without letting yourself be fooled.

Contents:  Wooden game board, two wooden stackers, twenty discs (10 blue, 10 red), instructions.

Name: Hold the Line: French and Indian War Expansion Set
Description:
From the website:

As a prelude to the American Revolutionary War, the French and Indian War shaped many of the future leaders and laid the seeds for that conflict. The French and Indian War expansion for the Hold the Line contains the following:

8 page color rule/scenario book
French army counters
Indian Warrior counters
British Roger's Rangers type counters
New hex tiles for Indian villages, open water, boats, forts and additional forest terrain tiles

The expansion has the followings 5 French and Indian War scenarios:

Battle on Snowshoes March 13, 1758: Rogers Rangers are ambushed by combined French and Indian forces. Greatly outnumbered, the Rangers must survive until night to make their escape.

Louisbourg June 8 1758: Against waiting French forces, British General Wolfe leads an amphibious landing of British light infantry and rangers to establish a beach head on Isle Royale.

Montmorecy Falls July 31, 1759: Combined British land and amphibious attack against the entrenched French army around Montmorency Falls in an effort to break the stalemate during the Quebec campaign.

Ste-Foy April 28, 1760: The French army attempt to recapture Quebec from the weakened British army in one of the hardest fought conventional battles of the French and Indian War.

Bloody Bridge July 31, 1763: British relief forces attack Pontiac's Indian village along the Detroit river in an attempt to lift the siege of Fort Detroit during Pontiac's war.

Expands

    Hold The Line

Name: Escape From Packet Hell
Description:
Introduction: If you're like me you only eat at the classiest of joints… you know places that have a napkin dispenser, a tray of sugar packets, and if you're lucky your own bottle of ketchup! No doubt the service is just wonderful too. Friendly, but slow. I created this game to play while waiting for your grease burger you ordered with extra grease.

Materials Required: 25 sugar packets, 2 players and 1 coin. (Don't lose that coin… it's your tip for after the meal!)

Object of the Game: When the coin lands on a player's home packet, that player has won.

Get the full game here:
http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

Name: Pocket Rocket Racers
Description:
The first in a series of games that can be carried in your wallet! This is a wild rocket race across your tabletop!

This game is best played on any tabletop littered with objects. These objects become the obstacles on the race course. The players should begin by defining the start line, the course through the obstacles and the finish line. The the racers should be placed power-side up at the start line.

Get the full game here:
http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

Name: Poly Wars
Description:
For hundreds of years they have watched others enjoy the glory of battle. They have helped heroes rescue the damsel in distress. They have won humans fortunes untold. They have decided the outcome of a million encounters. But never in all that time have they ever entered the battle as the hero or the damsel. Not a single coin has ever been won for them. Never has an encounter been theirs to experience.

At last, polyhedral dice have their chance! In this light tactical wargame, the players pit forces of dice against each other in mortal combat. There are no miniatures; the dice themselves fight their own battles. Now they can enjoy the glory of battle and so can you!

Name: Władca Żywiołów
Description: The newest Game by Lizardy for 2-4 players. It is about casting spells in order to change the weather. In fact it is rather abstract strategy game. The author (Krzysztof Matusik) is well known from previous Lizardy games (For example: Romeo and Juliet).

Name: Uncharted Lands
Description:
So what is it all about? The Uncharted Lands is a fantasy combat game that uses 28mm scale white metal miniatures. But it is also MUCH more than just a range of well sculpted figures.

The Uncharted Lands will act as the backdrop for all of our fantasy games, including our naval combat game.

The first races to be supported are Iron Dwarves and Orc Raiders. But we’re underway with our Humans and Dragon Lords. Shortly we will be making our Halfling Militia available and over time more races from The Uncharted Lands will appear.

We are developing a set of rules for the game and we hope to have more news for you on when these rules will be available. Right now we have 9 packs of miniatures (5 Iron Dwarf and 4 Orc Raiders) complete, each with 4 figures for foot troops or 3 figures for command.

We have greens for new figures, including an Orc commander and his brutish bodyguard and a cannon and crew for the Dwarves. We are busy with the design of our Dragon Lords and Humans, both races we’re sure you’ll like when they arrive.

Over time The Uncharted Lands will grow and new races will begin to unfold. The combination of naval game and land game is a novel one and we’re sure you’ll enjoy both. The Gallery below will give you an idea of what our miniatures look like when painted.

Name: TAKO
Description:
OBJECT OF GAME: The player to make the last legal move wins.

START: Make two piles of l1 stones. Each player rolls the die. Whoever rolls the highest value makes the first
move.

PLAY: Each player starts his/her turn by flipping a coin. If the coin lands heads up then the turn must be TAKO
HI. And if the coin lands tails up the turn must be TAKO LO. TAKO HI and TAKO LO affect how many stones
the player can remove from each pile in this turn. Then the player rolls the die and makes note of the value. Next
the player must make a legal move. Legal moves consist of:
1. Taking any number of stones from one pile.
2. Taking an equal number of stones from both piles.
3. Using an option move.

THE DESIGNER SAYS: As far as I can recall this is the first game I created that I actually committed to paper. I believe I created this game in 1992 or 1993. Based loosely on a mathematical game called Tsianshidsi, TAKO is a silly time wasting game.

According to the rules sheet, TAKO is pronounced take-o.

Full Rules Here:
http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

Name: Don't Touch My Booty
Description:
A silly little pirate game for 2 players! 
Goal: Arrrgghh! To be the pirate with the most booty at the end of the game, of course! This is done by creating rows of 3 or more coins.

Full Game Here:
http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

Name: Memoir '44: Operation Overlord
Description:
Take your game to the next level with Operation Overlord and relive the battles of WWII on a grand scale. With up to 4 players per side, you will soon experience the highs and lows of being part of a military-style chain of command.

Combined with an original copy of Memoir '44, this expansion includes all the material required to play Overlord games. Scenarios are not included; this expansion is designed to be played with our Memoir '44 Battle Map series of Overlord maps.

This expansion for Memoir '44 is part of the Memoir '44 series.

Name: The Simpsons: Go For It, Dude
Description: The object of the game is to be first to climb to the top of the grade chart. The cards are dealt face down to the players who then take turn to place their top-of-the-deck card face up in the middle of the table. When two cards with matching family members come up, the player that is first to slam his/her hysteria card in the middle gets to move up one step on the grade chart.

Name: Balancing Bob
Description: Balancing Bob sits atop a ladder mounted on a pivoting base.  Each player has three plastic paint cans that hook onto the ladder.  Based on a die roll, players move their cans up the ladder and eventually hang them on one of Bob's outstretched feet.  The first player to get all three of their cans onto Bob's feet without tipping over the ladder wins.

Name: Bee Bops
Description: Bee Bops features a motorized flower patch.  When activated, the flowers' pedals open to reveal "nectar disks".  Each player has, according to the rules, a "stick-on trigger action bee".  The trigger extends an arm with a suction cup at its end, which is used to collect the nectar disks.  The player who retrieves the most nectar wins.

Name: Safari Friends
Description: This children's game requires no reading, but helps to learn the animal names.  Each player is given a "character card" depicting an elephant, giraffe, tiger, or zebra.  Players attempt to create a copy of their animal out of four square tiles.  The tiles start stacked face down on cards depicting one of eight other animals.  On their turn, a player spins a spinner to determine which animal's stack they may draw from to find one of their missing animal pieces.  The player completing their animal first wins.

Name: Jeson Mor
Description:
Jeson Mor ("9 horses") is a two-player board game played on a 9x9 checkerboard that originates in Mongolia. This game was described in "The Encyclopedia of Chess Variants" (by David Pritchard).

Each horse moves like the Chess knight.
The goal of the game is to move one of your own horses to the middle cell of the board and then to move that horse outside the middle cell.

A player also wins if he captures all opponent's horses.

Name: Memoir '44: Hedgerow Hell
Description:
From the publishers website:

The Hedgerow Hell Memoir '44 Overlord BattleMap expansion includes a large-scale, double-sided map with two new Memoir '44 Overlord Scenario's - Hedgerow Hell and The Cadets of Saumur, plus 6 new Dodge Truck miniature figures. The oversized map, which is 57 x 27.5 inches in size, is ready-to-play with all terrain, obstacles and unit positions pre-printed - just add figures! It also features the scenario rules, terrain and unit summary cards, and historical background.

Perfect for group play at home or gaming events with fellow Memoir '44 friends, the Overlord BattleMap series is designed for 2 to 8 players and requires either 1 copy of the original Memoir '44 board game, plus the Operation Overlord Expansion; or 2 copies of the board game.'

Expands:

    Memoir '44 (2 copies required)


-or-

    Memoir '44: Operation Overlord (1 copy with the base game)
Families: Game: Memoir '44 – The Battle Map Series

Name: The Journey to Bethlehem
Description:
Game parts:

12 1/2 x 15 1/2 heavy folded board
Six pointed star spinner
3 wisemen on camels
3 shepherds

Game board shows the location of 145 Historic Places Famous in  Bible History.  The object of the game is to travel the roads and the first to get all their pieces to Bethlehem first wins.

Name: Singling Campaign
Description:
Singling Campaign Game is an historical module for Advanced Squad Leader that appeared in Operations Special Magazine Issue #1.

The game allows players to recreate the fighting at and around Singling, France which occurred 6 December 1944 between elements of the US 4th Armored Division and the German 11th Panzer Division.

Contents a full color 22" x 25.5" map and four pages of campaign specific rules (Z59-Z62).

The magazine also included two short scenarios SG1 and SG2 (but no SG Atlantis) for use with the map.

Name: Skedoodle
Description:
Skedoodle was published in Sid Sackson's A Gamut of Games.

It is a mathematical game where a master number is chosen among the following: 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 or 9 and, starting with a number from 1 to 30, players try to obtain the master number by the following operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication or division of the two digits of the chosen number. Players also score with a number that contains the master number written on it. The first player may not start the game with a scoring number. Then the next player must write another number using these same operations or by doubling, halving, squaring or taking the square root of the previous number. Each number from 1 to 30 may not be used more than once. The games ends when no further unused number between 1 to 30 can be derived from the actual number by the rules.

This game was presented to Sid Sackson by it author Father Daniel, with whom Sid Sackson exchanged correspondence about games in general.

Name: Nun Bowling
Description:
Nun Bowling, It's Sinfully Fun!

For 1 or more players

To bowl is human; the perfect game: divine.
You always knew sinning could be fun, but you never realized how much fun-until now. These STERN, ruler-armed, saintly sisters are just asking for retribution, whether you have Catholic school flashbacks or simply don't like their fashion sense. Strike back with the included 10 nun pins, ball of hellfire and 32-page book.

Name: Face to Face Paddington
Description:
Contents: 36 hexagonal tiles, each with 6 triangles showing pictures of Paddington in different colours.

Before you start, choose one of the figures shown on the side of the box. This should be used as model. All cards are divided amongst the players. The youngest player starts by laying one card face-up on the table. The player on his left-hand side then takes one of his cards and puts this next to the "open" card, in such a way that the previously chosen figure can be made. The cards have to be laid out face to face. When a player is unable to lay a card on the table, he has to skip a turn. The first player to lose all his cards is the winner.

Name: Sudoku Mania! Le défi
Description:
Contents:
- 1 book of rules
- 4 grids and 4 hiding screens of same colour
- 324 oval coins with figures
- 324 squared coins with figures
- 4 scoring boards and 4 pawns

The purpose is to be the quickest to solve a common Sudoku problem, each player having his own color for grid and numbers. The first to solve his grid wins 3 points, the second 2 points, and the third 1 point. First to raise 9 points is the winner.

The book of rules have 100 grids and solutions.

Name: BattleLore: For Troll and Country
Description:
The first installment in our series of Epic Adventures for BattleLore features two ready-to-play Adventure Maps in Epic format: For Troll and Country and Troll Bridge.

Each oversized map is ready-to-play with all terrain, obstacles and unit starting positions pre-printed - just add figures and play. It also features the adventure rules, summary cards and historical background. All this in English, French, and German.

Contents:

     Double-sided, large-scale Epic Adventure map including play details (heavy paper)
     Troll figure with Creature banner


The Troll's Creature card and the Stone Bridge card (printed on the map) were initially provided as PDFs on the company's web site. The Troll Creature card was later supplied with BattleLore: Dragons.

Expands:

     BattleLore

Name: Sangre y Fuego
Description:
Sangre y Fuego (Blood and Fire) is a solo game, of tactical urban fighting in Spanish Civil War.
Easy print and play recreates the battles for Belchite and Teruel.

Name: Pisa Gratto
Description: Similar to other Mechanism: Tower Stacking, players start with a tilted tower made of 1/2 cylinder pieces.  Players take turns removing one of the pieces from the tower and placing the piece on the top.  The player who is the last to stack a piece without causing the tower to topple is the winner.

Name: Im-Bi-Bo
Description:
extrapolated from Fair Play Games description.

This is a simple, abstract game of strategy for two.   Each turn players place cards on a small board hoping to pick up stones and, at the same time, control the value of those stones so they'll have the most points at the end of the game.

Name: Nuclear Renaissance
Description:
Nuclear Renaissance is a post apocalyptic themed, turn based, table-top strategy game. 
It uses 28mm figures and vehicles. Players play a gang of hardened fighters, pitting themselves against others in the wastelands of the future.

The Tome of Tridlins is a supplement for the game Nuclear Renaissance that really completes the game. The core game rules can be downloaded for free from the Ramshackle website or a printed version can be had from the web store. The Tome of Tridlins adds much more detailed gang design rules, along with a full campaign system and more background.

The main aspects of playing Nuclear Renaissance that sets it apart from other games are that it is great for multiple players and that the gang creation rules are really versatile.

The multi player aspect of the game makes it great for gaming groups. Three player games are easily handled, while even five or six players can get through a game in three hours or so. The rules are really designed so that any sized gaming group can have fun together without feeling that the person to go last is at a disadvantage, or that one player has to get left out. The game is biased towards playing campaigns, where players develop their gangs. The new book, the Tome of Tridlins, gives full rules for playing campaigns. This means that players can always get a game in a campaign even if only three people show up for a gaming night! What this comes down to is that gaming groups can easily fit the game around the players that show up and the boards that are available, rather than the other way around.

The gang creation rules were made with the idea of letting players play any type of gang that fits their fancy. Players can choose to play biker gangs, zombie hordes, all animal beast packs (monsters included), bands of mutants, robot death squads and even military conclaves. Players can even mix them all up, to have robot driven battle trucks packed full of mutants, zombies and wild animals with a mighty hero in charge! Vehicles are fully integrated into the game play and there are comprehensive but simple rules for designing ones that suit your gang. Within the gang design rules, players are set very few limitations. There are hundreds of options for making really unique forces. This complexity is condensed down onto simple gang rosters that can easily hold all the information you need to play with, without having masses of notes, counters, cards and other paraphernalia.

The problem with having very open gang design is keeping the game balanced. After six years of testing, the final result balances player gangs in a number of ways. The first is a points system, where each player is given a set amount to spend building their gangs. In campaigns the players are awarded more points as they play more games but the campaign system keeps players who miss gaming nights in the loop. Its easy to catch up, even if you lose! The second way to balance the game is that more power leads to less versatility. Power hungry "one man armies" don't get many tactical options and are often left waiting while the other players take their turns with larger gangs. The game works with players alternately activating characters, so gangs with the average ten or so members keep playing throughout a turn.

The game is aimed at players who want a new gaming system, nothing too complex to learn but with a lot of options. The game features solid mechanics and balance, which means that its robust enough to play well, but loose enough to let players use their imaginations. Power gamers can indulge their lust for super armoured laser cannon wielding death knights mounted on super bikes but will find that the other players in their gaming group will have the flexibility to constantly undermine their power gaming tactics. On the other hand, players who want to concentrate more on the theme of their gang will find that its easy to build forces that are powerful but have plenty of room for idiosyncrasies and whimsey!

Ramshackle Games already produces hundred of miniatures to play Nuclear Renaissance with. Players will find that most of the options in the books are covered in one form or another, so its easy to get a really thematic gang together right from the get-go.

Name: Cranium: Humdinger
Description:
A fast paced cooperative play game where you have to name the tune. Work together as a team to hum and guess all the answers before time runs out.

Easy to modify if there are large amounts of players or the players are quick to guess the answers: just pull out more cards and continue until timer is up.

Name: Cranium Cloodle
Description:
A fast paced cooperative play game where you have to figure out the clue that fits in the category. Work together as a team to draw and guess all the answers before time runs out.

Categories include: food, character, place, person, thing, band, action, and more!

Easy to modify if there are large amounts of players or the players are quick to guess the answers: just pull out more cards and continue until timer is up.

Name: Container: The Second Shipment
Description:
From Boardgame News Spiel 2008 Preview:

Container: The Second Shipment includes four different expansions that can be mixed and matched as players want. These expansions are:

Luxury Containers — In addition to the other containers, players add 12, 16, or 20 gold luxury containers to the supply. As a pre-turn action, a player can convert two containers in his factory or harbor to a gold container, pricing it as he wishes. Luxury containers are worth twice the number of luxury containers that a player collects, so one luxury container is worth 2, two containers are worth 8 (4 each), three are worth 18 (6 each), and so on.

Factory and Warehouse Restrictions — These two expansions work similarly, consisting of sets of cards that are stacked in a particular order. As you build more factories (or warehouses), a new restriction card takes effect, limiting the prices at which you can offer containers. In effect, these cards mimic economies of scale, allowing players to drop prices as they invest more in infrastructure.

Financiers — Players can now loan money directly to others, allowing them to earn the interest previously paid to the bank. A player who is looking for financing doesn't have to accept a loan offered by another player, but if she doesn't, then she must pass on borrowing money at all that turn. Competing Financiers may sweeten the deal by offering bigger loans for the same interest payment. Someone who defaults on a loan from another player will typically lose a container, factory, or warehouse to the lender to repay the debt.

Monopoly — A single player can now have more than one factory of the same color, potentially monopolizing production of a container type.

Name: Eendje kwaak
Description:
In this children's game, each player has a number bread crumbs that he should feed to the ducklings. There are five ducklings, each with a hidden colour (red, blue, green, yellow or orange).

Players take turns pressing the (electronic) mother duck. She'll either call a colour or quack. If she calls a colour, the player whose turn it is has to pick the duckling with the right colour. If he does so correctly, he may feed it a breadcrumb.

If the mother duck starts quacking, the player may move all the ducklings in the pond, until she stops quacking.

The first player to get rid of all his crumbs (by feeding them to the ducklings) wins the game.

Name: Burosh
Description:
Burosh is a game for 2-6 players. Each player has their own set of separately-colored six-sided dice, a communal board and set of Burosh playing cards (52 standard playing cards plus three custom wild cards).

Players take turns rolling and placing dice on the board, bolstering their dice and waning their opponents dice. Players try to build a good poker-esque hand of playing cards to use during challenges. The goal is to have the most points placed on the board when the board is full.

Name: Dwarf Tactic Minigame
Description:
This game is for 2 player, each act as the dwarf chief try to defend each castle and at the same time try to eliminate opponent's castle. you start with 10 castle point and resource at Lv 1 (which is 4 resource) and you need at least 2 six sided dice, game is played in turn.

For the rules you can read it on: http://experimentalplayground.blogspot.com/2008/08/dwarf-tactis-minigame.html

Name: Rock of Ages
Description:
Rock of Ages is a comprehensive music trivia game with popular music from the early 1950s up to 2008. 
Many of the questions relate to books, history and even movies through lyrical or thematic tie-ins. That, and many built-in clues, make Rock of Ages a challenging but user-friendly game.

Home Page: http://www.rockofagestrivia.com

Name: The Shadow of a Dark God
Description:
"The players will discover that the death of a friend is linked to a mysterious cult worshiping an immensely ancient deity."

The players control parties of six adventurers investigating the death of a good friend. The investigation leads the parties to search a cult temple. Hazards that may be faced by the adventurers include Rats, Traps, and the Horrible Old Ones.

A Cthulhu-inspired WarpQuest game to be played using the Artifact Core Rules.

Name: Lost Continent of Atlantis
Description:
Each player controls a party of six adventuring archaeologists and treasure hunters searching for the Pearl Trident of Atlantis.

The parties travel deep into the ocean by submarine, after which they don diving suits to explore the submerged Lost Continent. Hazards that may be faced by the adventurers include Undersea Pirates, Giant Squids, mutiny, and running out of air.

The party which returns to the surface with the Pearl Trident wins the game.

A WarpQuest game to be played using the Artifact Core Rules.

Name: Depths of the Earth
Description:
Each player controls a party of six adventuring archaeologists and treasure hunters journeying into the depths of the Earth in search of Dinosaur Eggs.

The parties traverse tunnels leading into the Earth's crust to reach a lost prehistoric realm hidden deep underground. Hazards that may be faced by the adventurers include Earthquakes, Lava, Mutant Albinos, Simian War Parties, and the dreaded Tyrannosaurus Rex.

The party to return to the surface with the Dinosaur Eggs wins the game.

A WarpQuest game to be played using the Artifact Core Rules.

Name: Mummys Tomb
Description:
Each player controls a party of six adventuring archaeologists and treasure hunters searching for a Pharaoh's treasure.

The parties journey through Egypt's Nile River Valley until they reach the Mummy's Tomb, which must then be explored. Hazards that may be faced by the adventurers include Sandstorms, Stubborn Camels, Serpent People, and the Mummy's Curse.

The party which exits the Nile River Valley with the Golden Treasure of the Pharaoh wins the game.

A WarpQuest game to be played using the Artifact Core Rules.

Name: Voyage of Sinbad
Description:
"Each player is an Arabian Swashbuckler Captain in search of Adventure & Fortune."

Each player controls a captain and seven crew members. Hazards that may be faced by the sailors include the Cyclops, Giant Walrus, Serpent Woman, and Sword Fighting Skeletons.

The players are racing to obtain a magic potion that will restore a cursed prince to his human form. The crew to return with the magic potion wins the game.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Quest for the Grail
Description:
Each player is a Knight of the Round Table searching for the Holy Grail. Knights are rated in a number of categories: Chivalry, Valor, Ranger, Sorcery, Seamanship, Wisdom, War, and Strength. Hazards that may be faced by the Knights include Mordred, the Black Knight, Plague, Brigands, and Pirates.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Pirate Island
Description:
Each player controls a pirate Expedition consisting of a captain, ship, and crew. An Expedition is rated for a number of characteristics: Crew, Cannon, Navigation, Discipline, Sailing, and Swashbuckling. Hazards that may be faced by the Expeditions include Spanish Galleons, Typhoons, Volcanic Eruptions, and Hostile Natives. The winner is the player who returns with the buried treasure.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Greek Heroes
Description:
"Each player controls a Greek Hero on a Quest to retrieve the Golden Fleece."

Each Hero is rated for a number of skills, including Wit, Strength, Archery, Swordsmanship, and Navigation. These skills are used to overcome foes and tests which face the Heroes, such as the Minotaur, Kraken, Labyrinth, Amazons, and Hydra.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Sharpe's Adventures
Description:
"Each player is a British Officer in Spain circa 1809. Based on the Sharpe’s Rifle Series of Books and Films by Bernard Cornwell." The players start out as Sergeants. The object of the game is to survive to reach the rank of Major.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Into the Valley of Death
Description:
"Simulation of the Charge of the Light Brigade, the final phase of battle of Balaclava in 1854."

"The player controls a British cavalry group of 12 men known as a ‘Troop’. All men are mounted on horses. All men are armed with a sword. One of the men is the Captain, the leader of the troop. Another man is the Trumpeter. The other 10 men are referred to as riders. There are 3 types of Troops: Dragoons, Hussars, and Lancers." The player chooses which type of Troop to use.

The object of the game is to charge the Russian gun battery and return, scoring as many points as possible. Points are earned for each surviving man in the Troop and for overcoming challenges.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Hidalgo
Description:
"Based on the Movie Hidalgo. Horse Race across the Arabian Desert. Each player (Pawn) represents a Rider & Horse."

The game is played on a track 50 spaces long, along which the players face survival and fighting challenges. The first player to reach the end of the track wins the race.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Surviving the Gulag
Description:
"The year is 1947 and the player is an Estonian patriot and resistance fighter that has been caught by the Russians and transported to Siberia to a brutal labor camp. The sentence is ten years of horrific conditions. The player has to survive the camp to return to the beloved Estonia."

"Resistance Fighter, Kalle Loodus, 33 years of age, former corporal in the Estonian Army during the independence, fought in Finnish Army during the War of Continuation, after the war returned to the Soviets by Finnish communist traitors, escaped and fought as a 'Forest Brother Guerilla Fighter' until caught and sent to labor camp in Siberia."

Hardships that may face the player include Scurvy, Tuberculosis, Forced Labor, and Torture.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: War Over the Reich
Description:
"Each player controls a Flight of 300 British (Halifax, Wellington, Mosquito, and Lancaster) Bombers on a Night Raid to bomb targets in Nazi Germany."

The players must get their Flight to the target, bomb the target, and return. The object is to earn the most victory points. Victory points are awarded for destroying targets and destroying enemy fighters. Victory points are lost when bombers are destroyed.

A variant set of cards is included to cover American daylight bombing raids.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Destroy the Rail Road Bridge
Description:
"The player controls a combat team of 5 Finnish Army Recon (Kaukopartio in Finnish) men in a mission far behind Soviet lines. The mission is to destroy a Rail Road Bridge 60 miles behind the enemy lines. It´s January 1943 and it's cold and dark in the Karelian woods."

"Each party consists of 5 members: Sergeant V.Korpi, Corpral J.Lahtinen, Jaeger M.Koskinen, Jaeger S.Berg, Jaeger S.Stenstrom. The Sergeant has 3 skills,  Corpral has 2 skills and Jaegers have 1 skill. The combat team is armed with 5 Suomi SMG's, 1 Sniper Rifle, Satchel Charges (AT weapon), mines, knives (the puukko's) and hand grenades. The team is carrying a radio. The team is skiing 60 miles to the target and 60 miles back to the Finnish lines."

The object of the game is to get your team safely to the bridge so that you can destroy it and then return. "When the combat team reaches home, they take a good 3 hour sauna bath, sleep a little and start another mission."

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Where Eagles Dared
Description:
"Movie 1968…. Commandos, posing as German soldiers, parachute into the Bavarian Alps to rescue a supposed allied general from a Nazi hideaway fortress that can only be reached by cable car. Epic war pic where Richard Burton and Clint Eastwood manage to unmask most of the German spy network in England, slip Jerry the wrong plans for the second front, kill the leading members of the Abwehr in Southern Bavaria, and destroy half of the local Wehrmacht."

Each player controls a Commando Team of seven agents - a major, an American Ranger lieutenant, two commandos, and three traitors. Other team members may be gained during play. The object of the game is to journey through the Alpine wilderness to the Castle of the Eagles, face three challenges, and then escape to a German airfield to be extracted in a disguised aircraft.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: In the Nam
Description:
"Your platoon has been de-assed in the bush. You must patrol the area and meet at a new pick-up point."

In this game set during the Vietnam War, each player starts with a platoon of forty-two men. The object of the game is to travel down the thirty space game track which abstractly represents time and distance. Along the way the platoon will face a variety of foes and booby traps. The object of the game is to amass the most Confirmed Kill points and survive with at least twenty men to be airlifted out.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Alien Queen Brain
Description:
"The players control a squad of space Marines in charge of freeing a command post overrun by alien forces."

Each player controls a landing party of six marines, consisting of one leader, one sergeant, and four soldiers. Each marine has a randomly determined set of skills. Available skills include xeno-biology, computer, mechanics, ground navigation, and morale.

The parties must travel from the drop zone to the overrun command post. Inside the command post is the Alien Queen which must be defeated. The party must then return to the drop zone with the Alien Queen Brain.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Beastmaster Quest
Description:
Each player is a Beastmaster, as depicted in the movie of the same name.

The object of the game is to be the first player to complete a Beastmaster Quest by reaching the last space on the sixty space game track. Along the way the players will face a variety of challenges, including treachery by the opposing Beastmasters.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: The Isle of Dread
Description:
"Based loosely on the old D&D Expert Rules system. This is a conversion of Dungeon Module X1 'The Isle of Dread'. Each player has an Adventuring Party in search of Adventure & Fortune. Each party is represented by a pawn on the track."

Each player controls a party of six adventurers. Each adventurer has a class (Fighter, Thief, Cleric, Magic User, Elf, Dwarf, or Halfling) and skills in three attributes (Stealth, Magic, and Fighting.)

The game is played on a track ninety spaces long, which abstractly represents distance and time. The game ends when the first party reaches the end space. The player who has the most gold at the end of the game wins.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Palace of the Silver Princess
Description:
"This Warp Quest Adventure is adapted from the D&D Basic Adventure Module Palace of the Silver Princess."

Each player chooses to play one of the following characters: Human Paladin, Dwarf Fighter, Aasimar Cleric, Human Wizard, or Elf Bard. The winner is the first player to reach the end of the thirty space long track on the game board. Along the way the players will face randomly drawn traps and monsters.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Rabbit Run
Description:
"Each player controls a Band of Rabbits who have left their overcrowded home Warren and are traveling the countryside, looking for a good spot to establish a new Warren. Based on the Novel Watership Down by Richard Adams."

The winner is the first player to have a band of rabbits reach the end the thirty-space game track.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Constantine
Description:
"Based on the movie Constantine, which was based on the comic Hellblazer. Each player is a Demon-Hunter/Exorcist."

Each Hunter is rated for the following attributes: Hit Points, Psychic, Contacts, Willpower, Combat, and Morality. The Hunters use these attributes to face Fight, Mental, and Info challenges.

The game is played on a track fifty spaces long. "The last represents the culmination of an infernal plot. The first player to the last space foils the plot and wins the game."

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Dantes Inferno
Description:
Each player controls a party consisting of three entities: a Renaissance poet, a blessed soul of heaven, and a pagan scholar holy soul. The party must undertake a quest to travel from Earth to hell, through the levels of hell, exiting into purgatoria, the last space on the board.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Score
Description:
"Each player takes the role of a teenager looking to Score on a Saturday night."

The players move pawns down a thirty space track facing an assortment of challenges: alcohol, sex, drugs, music, trouble and fight. When you win a challenge, you keep the Challenge Card. The player who acquires the most cards in the most challenge types wins the game.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: Jail Break
Description:
"Each player takes the role of a prisoner in Dick J. Pitt Correctional Facility Medium Security Prison looking to escape through a tunnel the prisoner is digging from his cell to freedom and then driving to Mexico."

The game is played on a track sixty spaces long. The first thirty spaces represent arranging the escape from prison. The second thirty spaces represent the journey to Mexico. Cards are drawn to provide random challenges and assistance. A player who wins a challenge keeps the Challenge Card. The player who acquires the most cards in the most challenge types wins the game.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

Name: drakkar
Description:
Contents: a square board 13×13, 30 tokens with an emblem printed on a face (6 different emblems), 8 pawns, 2 dices.
Each player is given 5 emblems, and his goal is to capture 5 tokens of this emblems. He can play his pawns or his tokens accordingly to the dices. Each time a player plays a pawn upon a token, he chooses between two actions: 
- to look secretly the emblem, then to put it back at his place, or 
- to take the emblem by flipping it. If it reveals to be one of those the player is looking for, he keeps it, else he must stay in jail for two moves.

Name: VR Troopers Game
Description:
From the back of the box:

"He's nasty! He's mean! He's Grimlord, the power-hungry master of virtual reality. And he's about to launch a deadly attack on the real world. Only you can stop him!

You and your friends must transform into VR Troopers and enter the mysterious world of virtual reality - just like on the exciting TV show! Toss the battle dice top smash the sinister Skugs. Your powers increase as you defeat them. Then fight the fiendish robot mutant General Ivar! But watch out! He'll stop at nothing to destroy you!

Only the bravest VR Troupers can defeat Grimlord's evil army and win the game. Will it be you?"

Unlike most other games, the three VR warriors in the game are shared by the players.  Each turn, the active player throws a die to decide which (red, yellow or green) trooper he controls this time, and then battle a Skug on their way to the penultimate battle, General Ivar.

Battles are done by tossing dice into a battle arena.  Someone plays the Skug and tosses one die, hoping for a hit (50% chance), and then the active player tosses a die to get a hit as well.  Play continues with 2 more dice on each side , one at a time. The dexterity comes in that you can try to hit your opponent's 'hit' die or your own 'miss' die to switch the result.  Ties go to the active player.

There is some skill in tossing the dice to change results, but because you cannot control which VR warrior you will assumer on your turn, the game comes down mainly to luck.  Winning battlers earns you a power chip (with a VR glasses wearing dog on it), which will allow you a reroll in the final battle (which is a toss of 4 dice at once, so dexterity plays no role here), while losing a battle loses you the same number of accumulated power chips.

There's no doubt this is a kid's game for fans of the TV show.  Still, the components are fairly nice and the battle arena mechanic is well done.

Name: The Letter Carrier Game
Description:
"People play letter carriers and maneuver through situations that aid and hinder them in making all deliveries safely and efficiently."

The object of the game is to optimize the delivery path and be the first to finish.

The board is made up of sixteen two-sided square tiles, featuring neighborhoods named after U.S. municipalities.  The game comes with 292 more pieces, including dice, hand-painted pawns, and "chance" cards, which feature obstacles (such as an angry dog), incidents (falling ice), transportation (bicycle), and helps (helmet).

Players can accumulate cards to help or sabotage an opponent.

The designer worked with his father, a retired letter carrier, to make the game as true-to-life as possible.

 Home Page: http://lettercarriergame.com/
Families: Theme: Mail / Stamps / The Post Office

Name: Die Siedler von Luxemburg
Description:
Die Siedler von Luxemburg is a scenario for the game The Settlers of Catan. It was created by the Luxemburg gaming club Guilde vun de Phantasiespiller for the national Catan championship 2008 and plays on a fixed map of the state of Luxemburg. The game includes the board, rules, and some additional components. A copy of Settlers is required for game play. Only 700 copies of the game were released, 300 of which were retained by Klaus Teuber and Kosmos for promotional events and corporate gifts.

Part of the Catan Series.

Name: Sol Invictus: The Copernican Wars
Description:
War has spread throughout the solar system, with factions using gravimetrics, atomics, and psionics to aid troopers as they invade and conquer planets to gain supremacy.

Star Fleet is fractured, Earth Command has become a vast telepathic neural net, and the asteroid belt is prey to teracorporations who parley with the Interplanetary Space Stations for peace.

In the midst of it all, an alien artifact mysteriously appears beyond the dwarf planet Pluto.

It is time to conquer the solar system in wars of the future.

Name: Defenders of ClayArt
Description:
Defenders of ClayArt is a game designed and published by B2FGames in Tachikawa, Japan. This game is currently sold by retailers in Japan only but whole components and the rulebook are written in English planned for worldwide publishing, though not yet achieved as of Aug. 2008.

Introductory text from the rulebook:

At a gallery in the city, or a studio in the countryside, snobbish artists, each thinking of him/herself as a defender of art, bicker with each other over works of "art". Much ado about nothing.(Welcome to the world of art critics. No talent necessary!)
You, as one of these artists, criticize the works. If your critique is pointed, you win the honor of being the true defender of art.
In this game, the players make clay sculptures with a certain theme, and criticize (rather than review) them. You can earn points when your critique matches the others'. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

Name: Barney Musical Parade Game
Description: This is a simple roll-and-move game for very young children.  Players roll an oversized die and move to the next space with a matching shape.  The die is electronic and plays the "I Love You" song, adding incessant joy to the game.  The first player to reach the end of the path wins.

Name: Great Dynasties of Europe
Description:
"Theme: European Royal Houses 1300-1900. Each turn represents 25 years (roughly 1 generation). Starting in 1300 and ending in 1900. There are 24 turns."

There are three custom card decks used in the game, the Dynasty Deck, Territory Deck, and Event Deck.

The Dynasty Deck represents the Dynasties that the players can represent. Each Dynasty has a starting Territory and a Special Ability. The Dynasties included in the game are: Habsburg, Orange, Tudor, Burgundy, Stuart, Romanov, Grimaldi, Hohenzollern, Oldenburg, Bourbon, Capetian, and Valois.

Each card in the Territory Deck represents a Territory that can be owned by a player. Each Territory belongs to one of ten Regions.

The Event Deck contains a variety of random events. Each turn a card is drawn from the Event Deck and resolved.

"Victory: The player with the most Victory Tokens at the end of the game wins."

Name: We Didn't Playtest This at All: Chaos Pack
Description:
Microbadge: 

This is the first expansion for We Didn't Playtest This at All

It contains fifteen "random and awesome cards to enhance your copy of We Didn't Playtest This at All

The new cards add additional rules to the game.  One is selected to be placed on the table at the start of each game or "If you're daring, place two."

Two blank cards to make your own rules are included.
Families: Game: We Didn't Playtest This At All
